keyTakeAways: Christopher Moynihan, a former Capitol rioter pardoned by President Donald Trump in 2021, has been arrested for allegedly threatening to kill U.S. House Minority Leader Hakeem Jeffries.
Moynihan allegedly planned to target Jeffries during a speech at the Economic Club of New York, with written messages expressing intent to kill him.
Moynihan was sentenced to 21 months in prison in 2023 for his role in the January 6 Capitol riot, where he was one of the first to breach police lines and take photos from a Senate desk.
Trump pardoned Moynihan and over 1,000 other riot defendants, calling them 'hostages' whose lives were 'destroyed', a move that has drawn criticism for enabling violent individuals to remain free.
Jeffries, a top Democratic contender for Speaker of the House, condemned the arrest as a necessary step to protect democratic institutions from domestic terrorism.
The case reflects broader concerns about political violence in the U.S., including recent deadly attacks on lawmakers and the dangerous normalization of lethal threats against public officials.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Christopher Moynihan, a man pardoned by former President Donald Trump for his role in the January 6, 2021 Capitol riot, has been arrested for allegedly threatening to kill U.S. House Minority Leader Hakeem Jeffries during a scheduled speech at the Economic Club of New York. Moynihan, who was sentenced to 21 months in prison in 2023 for breaching Capitol security and taking photos from a Senate desk, claims in text messages that Jeffries must be eliminated. Despite the pardon, law enforcement has intervened, with Jeffries praising the action as necessary to protect democratic institutions. This case underscores ongoing concerns about political violence in the U.S., including the normalization of lethal threats against elected officials, and raises questions about the consequences of executive pardons in the context of public safety.
title: Pardoned Capitol rioter arrested for allegedly threatening to kill Hakeem Jeffries
